R0: If a specific founder dies, team can't continue. 
R1: If all founders die, team can't continue.

R3: If all founders die, team motivated to and can continue.

1069310110130946049.text: Source: "Thinking, Fast and Slow" by Daniel Kahnemanhttps://www.goodreads.com/book/show/11468377-thinking-fast-and-slow …

1069310107824078848.text: Too much concern about how well one is doing in a task sometimes disrupts performance by loading short-term memory with pointless anxious thoughts.

1069310105513074688.text: In a state of flow, however, maintaining focused attention on these absorbing activities requires no exertion of self-control, thereby freeing resources to be directed to the task at hand.

1069310102891573248.text: Flow neatly separates the two forms of effort: concentration on the task and the deliberate control of attention. Riding a motorcycle at 150 miles an hour and playing a competitive game of chess are certainly very effortful.

1069310100547010561.text:
I found a satisfying evolutionary explanation for "flow".
People who experience flow describe it as "a state of effortless concentration so deep that they lose their sense of time, of themselves, of their problems"

1069295233521852416.text: Source: "The Righteous Mind: Why Good People Are Divided by Politics and Religion", amazing book recommended to me by @smpalladinohttps://www.goodreads.com/book/show/11324722-the-righteous-mind …

1069294440580304897.text: "Moral systems are interlocking sets of values, virtues, norms, practices, identities, institutions, technologies, and evolved psychological mechanisms that work together to suppress or regulate self-interest and make cooperative societies possible"

1069293775107829760.text: "Even today, markets that require very high trust to function efficiently (such as a diamond market) are often dominated by religiously bound ethnic groups (such as ultra-Orthodox Jews), who have lower transaction and monitoring costs than their secular competitors."
